steps: How often do you struggle to finish the final details of a project once the hardest part is already done?
How often do you find it hard to get things in order when you’re working on a task that requires organization?
How often do you have trouble remembering appointments or commitments?
When you have a task that requires a lot of thinking, how often do you avoid it or put off getting started?
How often do you fidget or move your hands and feet when you need to sit still for a long time?
How often do you feel overly active or driven to keep doing things, as if you’re being powered by a motor?
How often do you make careless mistakes when you’re doing boring or difficult work?
How often is it hard for you to stay focused when you’re doing dull or repetitive work?
How often do you find it hard to concentrate on what people are saying to you, even when they’re speaking directly to you?
How often do you lose things or have trouble finding them at home or at work?
How often do you get distracted by what’s going on around you or by background noise?
How often do you leave your seat in meetings or other situations where you’re expected to stay sitting for a long time?
How often do you feel restless or fidgety?
How often do you find it hard to relax and unwind when you have free time?
How often do you catch yourself talking too much when you’re around other people?
How often do you notice yourself finishing other people’s sentences before they can finish them themselves?
How often is it hard for you to wait your turn?
How often do you interrupt other people when they’re busy?

0.text: People with ADHD often find it hard to keep their attention on one task for a long time, so they may struggle to finish a project even when the hardest part is already done.
0.fact: Difficulties with finishing projects are often linked to procrastination or perfectionism. A person may delay completing a task because they’re afraid the result won’t be “good enough”.

1.text: Executive dysfunction, which is often associated with ADHD, affects a person’s ability to plan, organize and complete tasks. Because of this, keeping things in order can feel especially challenging.
1.fact: The more tasks and items someone has to keep in mind, the harder it becomes to maintain order. For people with ADHD, this sense of overload tends to arise more often.

2.text: Working memory plays a key role in remembering appointments and commitments. It’s the short-term storage we use to hold important information while we go about our day. People with ADHD often have difficulties with working memory, which can lead to forgetting important things.
2.fact: Studies suggest that around 40–60% of adults with ADHD report significant forgetfulness, especially when it comes to scheduled meetings and promises they’ve made.

3.text: Parkinson’s law says that work tends to expand to fill all the time available for it. When there is no clear deadline, it becomes much easier to delay starting a demanding task, and procrastination can stretch out for a long time.
3.fact: French writer Victor Hugo was known for extreme methods of fighting procrastination: he would have his clothes taken away so he couldn’t leave the house and stayed in his room until he finished writing a book.

4.text: Hyperactivity is one of the core symptoms of ADHD. It can show up as constant fidgeting, tapping feet or moving hands, especially when a person is expected to sit still for a long period of time.
4.fact: Singer and actor Justin Timberlake has spoken about living with both ADHD and obsessive–compulsive disorder. He has said that moving and fidgeting sometimes helps him cope with tension and anxiety.

5.text: Feeling as if there is a “motor running inside” is a classic description of hyperactivity, especially in people with ADHD. This state is marked by constant physical activity and an inner inability to relax.
5.fact: Actor Sir Anthony Hopkins has described how ADHD contributed to a sense of inner drive, and how he learned to channel this energy into his work and creative projects.

6.text: Boring or repetitive tasks often lower attention and concentration, which increases the risk of careless mistakes. When a task is not engaging, it is harder for the brain to maintain focus.
6.fact: Complex tasks require significant cognitive resources. People with ADHD often find it difficult to manage these resources, which can lead to more errors made out of inattention.

7.text: The brain has limited attentional resources. When work is dull and monotonous, it quickly loses interest and starts seeking something more stimulating, which makes it harder to stay focused.
7.fact: Richard Branson, founder of the Virgin Group, has admitted that he finds it difficult to stay focused on boring tasks. He delegates routine work to his team so he can concentrate on more creative and engaging areas of the business.

8.text: ADHD affects the brain’s executive functions, which can make it hard to stay focused during conversations, especially when they require sustained attention.
8.fact: Research shows that about 60% of adults with ADHD experience difficulties concentrating on what others are saying. This can create challenges in both personal and professional relationships.

9.text: People with ADHD often struggle with forgetfulness and organization, which can lead to frequently losing or misplacing things. This is linked to difficulties with working memory and planning.
9.fact: Actress Carrie Fisher, known for her role as Princess Leia in Star Wars, spoke openly about ADHD and joked about how often she lost things, using humour and practical strategies to cope.

10.text: Many people with ADHD have increased sensory sensitivity, which makes them more reactive to external stimuli such as noise or movement. This can result in frequent distractions.
10.fact: Being pulled away by background sounds or events is a common difficulty in modern life. Psychologists sometimes refer to this as the challenge of “divided attention” in a world full of stimuli.

11.text: Hyperactivity, a core ADHD symptom, can make it hard to remain seated for long periods. People may feel a strong need to get up, move around or change position.
11.fact: Around 4–5% of adults with ADHD experience significant problems with hyperactivity, which can show up as restlessness and difficulty staying seated in formal settings.

12.text: Feelings of anxiety and inner restlessness have deep evolutionary roots. These emotions once helped our ancestors stay alert in dangerous situations, preparing the body to act quickly.

13.text: Many people with ADHD find it hard to relax even in their free time because of a constant sense of inner tension and a drive to stay busy.
13.fact: Chronic stress keeps the body in a state of “readiness”, making it difficult to switch into rest mode. Over time this can interfere with sleep, recovery and the ability to enjoy leisure.

14.text: Fast, racing thoughts, which are common in ADHD, can lead to rapid and continuous talking. This is especially noticeable in social situations that are rich in stimulation.
14.fact: Actor Robert Downey Jr. has spoken about his high energy and quick speech, and how creativity and acting help him channel these traits in a constructive way.

15.text: Because thoughts can run ahead very quickly in ADHD, a person may feel they already know what the other person is going to say and start finishing their sentences. This often comes from impatience and a wish to speed up the conversation.
15.fact: Difficulties with impulse control and active listening can make it harder to wait until the other person finishes. Learning communication skills can help reduce this behaviour.

16.text: People with ADHD often struggle with executive functions such as planning, impulse control and delaying gratification. Because of this, waiting for one’s turn can feel especially difficult.
16.fact: Studies show that impulsivity and difficulty waiting can negatively affect relationships, work performance and overall quality of life, and may lead to conflicts with others.

17.text: Interrupting others is a common sign of impulsivity in ADHD. It happens because it is hard to hold back thoughts or the urge to speak right away.
17.fact: Actor Johnny Depp has talked about how challenging it can be not to interrupt people. He notes that practices such as mindfulness and conscious listening help him communicate more calmly.

low.text: Your result suggests a low likelihood of ADHD-related symptoms. In general, you are able to maintain concentration, manage impulses and organize your actions. This does not rule out occasional difficulties with attention — they can happen to anyone, for example due to stress, fatigue or overload. If you still notice that focus or self-control is sometimes hard and this affects your quality of life, talking to a specialist can help clarify the causes and find suitable support.
low.title: Low likelihood of ADHD

middle.text: Some of your answers may be related to ADHD symptoms, such as difficulty concentrating, impulsivity or increased distractibility. This does not mean that you definitely have ADHD — similar signs can also be linked to stress, lack of sleep, anxiety or emotional strain. If these features interfere with your daily life, it may be helpful to discuss them with a professional to better understand what is going on and get personalised recommendations.
middle.title: Moderate likelihood of ADHD

high.text: Your answers may point to marked difficulties with attention, self-regulation and resistance to distractions. These patterns can affect work, study and everyday life. This test does not provide a diagnosis, but it can be a reason to seek a full assessment from a qualified specialist. Getting supportive guidance or treatment, if needed, can significantly improve quality of life and reduce daily stress.
high.title: High likelihood of ADHD

text: Symptoms of ADHD — such as difficulty concentrating, impulsivity and increased distractibility — can appear in many people, especially under stress or overload. This test helps you notice possible patterns and understand whether it might be useful to talk them over with a specialist.
Only a qualified clinician can diagnose ADHD. This test is designed for adults. If you would like to assess a child’s condition, it is better to consult a child specialist.
